quiz.title: Chemistry: Unit 1 Quiz 8
quiz.subtitle: 1.8: Heating Techniques: Bunsen Burners and Hot Plates
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Safe heating procedures in the lab

questions.question: When lighting a Bunsen burner, what is the correct order of operations?
options: Turn on gas, then strike the match.
Strike the match/striker first, then slowly turn on the gas.
Open the air vents fully, then turn on the gas.
Blow into the tube to clear it, then light it.
questions.explanation: To prevent a large buildup of gas that could cause a small explosion or 'poof,' always have your spark or flame ready before opening the gas valve.

questions.question: Which part of a Bunsen burner flame is the hottest?
options: The very top of the outer yellow flame.
The base of the burner.
The tip of the inner blue cone.
The middle of the orange section.
questions.explanation: The inner blue cone is the site of complete combustion and is the hottest part of the flame.

questions.question: If the flame on your Bunsen burner is yellow and 'lazy,' what adjustment should you make?
options: Turn up the gas pressure.
Open the air vents (collar) to allow more oxygen.
Close the air vents completely.
Turn off the gas and start over.
questions.explanation: A yellow flame indicates incomplete combustion due to a lack of oxygen. Opening the collar mixes more air with the gas for a hotter, blue flame.

questions.question: Why is a hot plate often preferred over a Bunsen burner when heating flammable liquids like ethanol?
options: Hot plates heat up faster.
Hot plates don't use electricity.
Hot plates provide heat without an open flame, reducing fire risk.
Hot plates are easier to clean.
questions.explanation: Flammable vapors can catch fire easily from an open flame; a hot plate (especially one without exposed coils) is much safer for heating volatile substances.

questions.question: What is the purpose of adding 'boiling chips' or 'boiling stones' to a liquid before heating?
options: To speed up the boiling process.
To prevent 'bumping' and ensure smooth, even boiling.
To change the color of the liquid when it's done.
To keep the liquid from evaporating.
questions.explanation: Boiling chips provide nucleation sites that allow bubbles to form calmly, preventing the liquid from suddenly splashing out of the container (bumping).

questions.question: When using a hot plate with a magnetic stirrer, what is the small white rod placed inside the beaker called?
options: Stirring stick
Magnetic flea or stir bar
Conductivity rod
Heating element
questions.explanation: A magnetic stir bar is rotated by a spinning magnet inside the hot plate to mix the solution automatically as it heats.

questions.question: How can you tell if a glass beaker is hot just by looking at it?
options: It will turn a slight red color.
It will steam constantly.
You cannot tell; hot glass looks exactly like cold glass.
It will vibrate slightly.
questions.explanation: This is a major lab hazard. Always use tongs or heat-resistant gloves if you suspect a piece of glassware has been recently heated.

questions.question: Which of the following should NEVER be heated in a closed container (like a flask with a stopper)?
options: Water
Saltwater
Any substance
Only flammable chemicals
questions.explanation: Heating a sealed container causes gas pressure to build up rapidly, which can lead to the container exploding.

questions.question: What is the 'safety flame' on a Bunsen burner?
options: A roaring blue flame.
A flame that has been turned off.
A cool, bright yellow flame with the air vents closed.
A flame that is only 1 cm high.
questions.explanation: The yellow flame is called the safety flame because it is visible and cooler than the blue flame, making it safer when the burner is not actively being used.

questions.question: True or False: You should always reach over a Bunsen burner to adjust the gas tap.
options: True
False
questions.explanation: False. Never reach over a flame; your sleeve or hair could catch fire. Always approach the controls from the side.
